name: thermal storage system construction, solar thermal parabolic trough, 50 MW | thermal storage system, solar thermal parabolic trough, 50 MW | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/18218/documentation

This activity represents the construction of a hot and cold two stage nitrate salt thermal storage system for a 50 MW solar thermal parabolic trough power plant. The main components in this activity are nitrogen pressure vessels, storage tanks, pumps, pipes, electrical wiring and insulation and finally concrete and paint works. The storage tanks are designed for 3-6 hour storage time. The heat storage capacity as calculated for the present CSP plant design amounts to 1100 MW. ;This dataset is entirely based on the detailed life cycle inventory as presented in the dissertation report by ;Telsnig, Thomas. 2015. Standortabhängige Analyse und Bewertung solarthermischer Kraftwerke am Beispiel Südafrikas. Forschungsbericht. Band 123. ISSN 0938-1228. Institut für Energiewirtschaft und Rationelle Energieanwendung, Universität Stuttgart, Germany.

The activities start with preparation of the molten salt made of NaNO3 and KNO3 60% and 40% by weight mixture respectively. The thermal storage capacity is designed at 1100MWh for a 50MW parabolic trough limited storage case. 

The activity concludes with the decommissioning of the plant with the construction materials sent for recycling and disposal according to their treatment methods.
category: F:Construction/42:Civil engineering/422:Construction of utility projects/4220:Construction of utility projects

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The CSP plant represented in this dataset has been modelled specifically for South African conditions (see Telsnig 2015).
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Nitrogen storage vessel - Horizontal, cylindrical tank, ASTM A 516, Grade 70, carbon steel, 14 ft diameter,51ft long, 35 psig design pressure, 0.25 inch wall thickness, 27000 lb vessel mass;;Cold storage tank - Vertical cylindrical tank, self supporting roof, atmospheric pressure 102 ft diameter x 46 ft height, ASTM A 516, Grade 70, carbon steel, 710000 lb approx. Weight.;;Hot storage tank - Vertical cylindrical tank, self supporting roof, atmospheric pressure 104 ft diameter x 46 ft height, ASTM A 516, Grade 70, carbon steel, 750000 lb approx. Weight;Oil-to-salt Heat Exchangers - Straight shell, U-tube, 424000ft² heat transfer aera each, carbon steel shell, tubes tubessheet and channel 170000lb empty weight each;Nitrogen-to-air Heat Exchangers - Finned tube, forced draft heat exchanger, 50 ft² bare tube area, 650ft² finned tube area, 0.75 bhp electric fan;Cold Salt Pumps - Extended Shaft turbine pump, 2 stages, 14000gpm, 3705 lb/sec, 192ft total developed head, 1750 bhp motor variable speed drive;Hot Salt Pumps - Extended Shaft turbine pump, 2 stages, 14400gpm, 3705 lb/sec, 200ft total developed head, 1750 bhp motor variable speed drive;Spare Pump and motor (without variable speed drive) - Extended Shaft turbine pump, 2 stages, 14400gpm, 3705 lb/sec, 200ft total developed head, 1750 bhp motor;Piping: Carbon steel pipes of Grade B;Valves: Carbon steel valves
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The original data modelling a 250 MW power plant have been scaled down with parameter specific linear and non-linear equations to represent a 50 MW plant design.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
This dataset is entirely based on the detailed life cycle inventory as presented in the dissertation report by 
Telsnig, Thomas. 2015. Standortabhängige Analyse und Bewertung solarthermischer Kraftwerke am Beispiel Südafrikas. Forschungsbericht. Band 123. ISSN 0938-1228. Institut für Energiewirtschaft und Rationelle Energieanwendung, Universität Stuttgart, Germany. 
Further, data in Telsnig 2015 are not shown explicitely for the downscaled 50 MW parabolic trough power plant. This gap is filled in the ecoinvent report.

exchanges.description:
Nitrate salt discharge at the end of the power plant lifetime. For a lack of available data, it was assumed that 15% of nitrate salts are lost during operation or discharge. This estimate is considered conservative. However, at the point of dataset creation the end of the lifetime of first generation CSP plants lies at least 30 years into the future. Therefore, the fate of nitrate salts used in these plants remains uncertain. It is currently assumed that they can be reused in future plants
It is indicated by Bradshaw et al. (2002) that nitrate salts which cannot be recovered or reused need to be treated as hazardous waste.
Reference(s): 
W. BRADSHAW, ROBERT & B. DAWSON, DANIEL & DE LA ROSA, WILFREDO & GILBERT, ROCKWELL & H. GOODS, STEVEN & Hale, Mary Jane & JACOBS, PETER & A. JONES, SCOTT & Kolb, Gregory & Pacheco, James & R. PRAIRIE, MICHAEL & E. REILLY, HUGH & Showalter, Steve & vant-hull, Lorin. (2002). Final Test and Evaluation Results from the Solar Two Project. 10.2172/793226.

exchanges.description:
All steel types are assumed to be treated as reinforcing steel due to lack of other appropriate datasets in ecoinvent.  
For the time period 2003-2012, average steel recycling rate in South Africa amounted to 35% fo the total steel mass according to Telsnig 2015. The remaining steel is assumed to be sent to final disposal.
